please just put in port.hpp.  There's no need to create a new utils namespace for something only used in one module.

The reason to have another file (`port_utils.hpp`) is because the same function is used in 2 different files and they are inter-dependent.
- `fabric_adapters.upp` - uses 'getPortList()'
- `port.hpp` includes  `fabric_adapters.hpp` and the function 'getPortList()'.

Due to those reasons, I used `port_utils.hpp`.

If we need to remove the file (`port_utils.hpp`), it needs to put into `fabric_adapters.hpp`.
I felt that the function `getPortList()` seems more relevant to `port` than `fabric_adapters`.

Please let me know if it is more preferred to put it into `fabric_adapters.hpp`.

Should this be using the current version of the schema since this is the first time we are supporting this one?

(#Port.v1_10_0.Port is what we have in Port.json)

As this commit does not implement the new attributes for v1_8_0 or higher, it is not necessary to set the currently highest Port schema version (e.g. v1_10_0).

When we need to implement the features in the higher schema versions, the version would need to be increased.

Redfish told use the latest version you need, not necessary the latest version. This gives the client some clues of what you support (chassis and powersubsystem/thermalsubsystem was their example). 

I think this 1_7_0 fits best with our existing versions. Our versions are a mess and 
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/54030 moves to generating them. One side effect of 54030 is, it will move us to the latest versions of each resource.

Similar type of the implementation is done for the other areas.
One example is https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/3e7a8da60d70f4c42ae8ce0a3ecb0709194eb831/redfish-core/lib/power_supply.hpp#L148

I removed the redundant emptiness check and I remove the function `checkPortId()`.
Generally callbacks are not called in a loop (although there are some unforunate exceptions).  Please model this as a single callback.

The loop is to find a matching one and then do a single callback() before return.
```
   callback(portPath);
   return;
```

The similar style was done in the other places like 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/3e7a8da60d70f4c42ae8ce0a3ecb0709194eb831/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp#L235C1-L242C10

Yes, there are exceptions, but in general, we try to follow the boost style, which is a single callback for a given async action.  That makes control flow and object lifetimes easier to track.  The example you gave follows an anti-pattern of ignoring the callback in error cases.
Non trivial lambda.

Similar code patterns exist in the other places - e.g. fabric_adapters.hpp, or pcie.hpp

Anyway, I refactored the function body and rename the function name  
 to `getValidFabricPortPath()` for better clarity.

Why are we looking for a valid fabric adapter path first? Generally we would want to look for a port with a matching name, then verify that it has a system association.

Doing it the way it's done here results in significantly more dbus calls.

This is for `/redfish/v1/Systems/<str>/FabricAdapters/<str>/Ports/<str>/` among many other types of Ports.

Fabric adapter ports are specific to each fabric adapter, and the association is also related to each fabric adapter.
So, to get the port, the fabric adapter path name needs to be obtained.

This commit is doing the followings to find the associated port and it would do 2 dbus calls.

 - GetSubTree() get/validate the fabric adapter path
 - GetAssociatedTreePaths() to get ports using the found fabricAdapterPath.
 
However, if we change to too for ports first, it may end up causing more d-bus calls.

For example, assuming ports exist for other entities, GetSubTree() for a port (e.g. port1) may find this first
- .../network1/port1
- .../storge1/port1
- .../fabric1/port1
- etc

Then, to choose/select the fabric adapter (e.g. fabric1), we may need to call the assoication d-bus calls for each port (as the port-list may be associated with the different types).  
As the result, the total number of dbus could become larger than finding the fabric adapter first.

In addition, for better clarity, I've renamed `port.hpp` to `fabric_ports.hpp`, and rename function names to include `Fabric` e.g. `getValidFabricPortPath()`
This is a 3 scope deep lambda.  This is a common documented error.

I've refactored the function `getValidFabricPortPath()` to get the port in 1-level.

IBM uses PLDM (using openpower-vpd-parser) to implement this instead of usign EM.
The related commits are:
- https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openpower-vpd-parser/+/66540
- https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/66541

How can PLDM detect a fabric adapter?  Wouldn't a fabric adapter be based on an eeprom fru connected to the BMC?

In the commit you linked, I see:

"xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Connector.Port": null,


So it's not filing out any of the port properties?
What I learned about it is that hypervisor is sending down the fabric adapter via pldm.

From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypervisor

"IBM provides virtualization partition technology known as logical partitioning (LPAR) on System/390, zSeries, pSeries and IBM AS/400 systems. For IBM's Power Systems, the POWER Hypervisor (PHYP) is a native (bare-metal) hypervisor in firmware and provides isolation between LPARs. .... "
So, we're talking about virtualized Fabric adapters.  Shouldn't those go into hypervisor_system?

Even if the fabric adapters/ports are created by the hypervisor, wouldn't the fabric adapters still be classified as FabricAdapters and their ports?

(I also think the physical Fabric Adapters may provide the ways to create virtual ports for the VMs?)

> Even if the fabric adapters/ports are created by the hypervisor, wouldn't the fabric adapters still be classified as FabricAdapters and their ports?

If they're created by the hypervisor, they would go in the hypervisor system, not the physical system, as you've put them here.

> 
> (I also think the physical Fabric Adapters may provide the ways to create virtual ports for the VMs?)

Right, that's the difference.  Physical fabric adapters go in the physical system, virtual fabric adapters go in the hypervisor system.  Because these are created by the hypervisor, they would go in the hypervisor system.
Why was this added?

This is a one line function.  Just put it inline with the other things setting up fabric adapter.  Unless you intend to unit test it or reuse it, there's not really any reason to have a one line function.
Done.
